concern: I am terrified of going to college because I have debilitating anxiety. I am extremely fearful of talking and interacting with people outside of my family at home but I have never been allowed to get an actual diagnosis. Will I have to find a way to get a diagnosis so that I can be excused from any social assignments/classes? I assume that’s the only way they would allow it

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome! I'm glad you're here. Feel free to share anything that's on your mind or any concerns you might have.

Thanks. It's just that college feels really overwhelming, and I'm scared about dealing with my anxiety on top of everything else. I'm not sure how to handle social situations or if I need a diagnosis to get some kind of accommodation.
It sounds like you're feeling overwhelmed and unsure about how to navigate social situations and potential accommodations. What's been your experience with anxiety so far?
client: It's been pretty intense. I feel paralyzed in social situations and like I'm constantly on edge, especially around people I don't know well.
It sounds really tough to feel paralyzed and constantly on edge in social settings. How long have you been experiencing these feelings, and have there been any situations where you felt more at ease?
client: I've felt like this for as long as I can remember, honestly. There are rare moments, usually when I'm with my family or close friends, where I feel a bit more relaxed, but it's not often.
It sounds like being with family or close friends provides some relief from your anxiety. What do you think it is about those situations that makes you feel more at ease?
I think it's just the comfort of knowing I'm not being judged and feeling accepted no matter what. It's like a safe space where I can just be myself without fear.

That sense of acceptance and being able to be yourself sounds really important. How do you think your life might be different if you could carry that feeling of safety and acceptance into other situations?

I can't even imagine what that would be like, honestly. It would change everything—maybe I'd actually feel comfortable enough to participate and not constantly worry about how I come across to others.

It sounds like carrying that feeling of safety and acceptance with you could really open up new possibilities. What small steps do you think could help cultivate that kind of comfort in more situations?
client: Maybe just starting with one-on-one interactions or smaller groups could help. I guess practicing in less overwhelming settings might make it a bit easier to gradually build my confidence.
That sounds like a thoughtful approach, starting small and building your confidence gradually. How do you feel about the idea of trying this out in smaller settings?
It sounds like a good idea in theory, but even small settings can feel pretty daunting. I guess I'm just worried about freezing up or saying something weird and making things awkward.
It's understandable to feel concerned about those moments. What might help you feel a bit more at ease or prepared when entering those smaller settings?
client: Maybe having some kind of plan or topics in mind could help, so I don't feel totally lost. Also, reminding myself that it's okay to have awkward moments might ease some of the pressure.

Having a plan and reminding yourself that awkward moments are okay sound like strong strategies. Would you like to set a goal of preparing a few conversation topics for your next gathering, and maybe practice self-compassion when awkwardness arises?
Yeah, I think setting that goal could be helpful. Preparing a few topics might give me a little more confidence, and I’ll try to be kinder to myself when those awkward moments do happen.
Great, that sounds like a solid plan. How about we discuss how you'll choose and prepare those topics, and ways you might practice self-compassion, so you feel more ready for your next gathering?

Sure, that sounds like a good next step. I think maybe focusing on interests like books or shows could be a starting point, and I'll try to remind myself that everyone has awkward moments, not just me.

It sounds like you've established a solid foundation for moving forward. You've set a goal to prepare conversation topics around your interests, like books or shows, which is a great way to feel more confident in social settings. Remembering that it's okay to have awkward moments and practicing self-compassion are important steps in managing your anxiety. Keep reminding yourself that everyone experiences awkwardness, and that's perfectly normal.

Your next step is to spend some time preparing those topics and practice talking about them, perhaps with a family member or friend, to build your confidence. Remember, you're doing great by taking these steps, and I'm here to support you as you continue to work on these goals. Keep up the good work!
Thanks, I appreciate the encouragement. I'll definitely try to prepare some topics and practice talking about them with someone I trust.
